dialogues.text: Wait!! You wanted, what was it, tax man for the Western Reserve, hell you can have the whole state of Ohio if you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bilbo stops, winded.

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aw, crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward, smoking unhappily, strides toward his carriage, w Schell, Latham and Bilbo in pursuit. 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven votes?! Two days ago we had twelve!! What happened?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD SCHELL ROBERT LATHAM
dialogues.text: It's the goddamned rumors There are defections in the regarding the Richmond ranks... Yes! The peace delegation. offer!

dialogues.speaker: SEWARD ROBERT LATHAM
dialogues.text: Groundless. I told you that. And yet the rumors persist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are ruining us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the few remaining representatives who seem remotely plausible there is a perceptible increase in resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward has reached the carriage, Bilbo alongside him. Bef the Secretary of State can climb on board, Bilbo shuts th carriage door. Seward is outraged.

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Resistance, hell! Thingamabob Hollister, Dem from Indiana? I approached him, the sumbitch near to murdered me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bilbo is talking to HAROLD HOLLISTER (D, IN), who pulls o derringer. Bilbo bolts, dropping the folder. He stops, ru back, and bends to retrieve the folio as Hollister fires gun over Bilbo's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward, now inside the carriage, slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you push too hard.

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: I push nobody. Perhaps we need reinforcements. If Jeff Davis wants to cease hostilities, who do you think'll give a genuine solid shit to free slaves? 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back to it, and good day, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schell and Latham lean in to the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are at an impasse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Lincoln to deny the rumors. Publicly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us what you expect of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect you to do your work! And to have sufficient sense and taste not to presume to instruct the President. Or me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schell steps up on the running board, intent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a Confederate offer or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ULYSSES S. GRANT, 43, 5'7", beard, uniform worn and rumpl crosses the dock, followed by three aides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach the gangway for the River Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant and the commissioners stand in an expansive cabin a the stern, patriotically decorated, large windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant hands the commissioners' peace proposal back to the He's scribbled notes all over the document.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suggest you work some changes to your proposal before you give it to the President.

dialogues.speaker: R.M.T HUNTER
dialogues.text: We're eager to be on our way to Washington. 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Lincoln tell you to tell us this, General Grant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant fixes Stephens with a look - bemused, a little disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says..."securing peace for our two countries." And it goes on like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just one country. You and I, we're citizens of that country. I'm fighting to protect it from armed rebels. From you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mr. Blair told us, he, he told President Davis we were -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private citizen like Preston Blair can say what he pleases, since he has no authority over anything. If you want to discuss peace with President Lincoln, consider revisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're not to discuss a truce between warring nations, what in heaven's name can we discuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terms of surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a somber Grant disembarks with his aides from the Rive

dialogues.speaker: GRANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Office United States Military Telegraph, War Dept. For Abraham Lincoln, President of the United States. January 20, 1865. I will 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: state confidentially that I am convinced, upon conversation with these Commissioners, that their intentions are good and their desire sincere to restore peace and union. I fear now their going back, without any expression of interest..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward's voice takes over from Grant's.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "...from anyone in authority, "...from anyone in authorit Mr. Lincoln..." Mr. Lincoln..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward's in a fancy robe and slippers, reading a telegram

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...will have a bad influence. I will be sorry should it prove impossible for you to have an interview with them. I am awaiting your instructions. U.S. Grant, Lieutenant General Commanding Armies United States"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is in his coat, shawl over his shoulders, holding hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After four years of war and near 600,000 lives lost. He believes we can end this war now. My trust in him is marrow deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward looks up at Lincoln, then down again at the telegr He stands and crosses to Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could bring the delegates to Washington. In exchange for the South's immediate surrender, we could promise them the amendment's defeat. They'd agree, don't you think? We'd end the war. This week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln has closed his eyes. 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or. If you could manage, without seeming to do it, to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln shakes his head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peace delegation might encounter delays as they travel up the James River. Particularly with the fighting around Wilmington. Within ten days time, we might pass the Thirteenth Amendment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln, shawl still wrapped around him, walks the long e hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln sits before an open window. He's dishevelled, in shirtsleeves an unbuttoned vest, next to an inkwell, pape and books of law scattered about, and a lit candle in a candlestick, guttering. Grant's telegraph is in one hand, in the other hand, his spectacles and, dangling from a ch his open pocket watch. His bare left foot keeps time with watch's loud ticking. He stares out into the cold night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is spare and neat. Nicolay and Hay are asleep in their beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is sitting at the foot of Hay's bed, spectacles o reading a petition, the others in his lap, pencil in hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, here's a sixteen year old boy. They're going to hang him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hay startles awake, then settles. He's used to this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he reads a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was with the 15th Indiana Calvary near Beaufort, seems he lamed his horse to avoid battle. I don't think even Stanton would 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: complain if I pardoned him? You think Stanton would complain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolay stirs in the next bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummm... I don't know, sir, I don't know who you're, uh... What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's three forty in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not waking up:) Don't... let him pardon any more deserters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolay's asleep again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Stanton thinks you pardon too many. He's generally apoplectic on the subject -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He oughtn't to have done that, crippled his horse, that was cruel, but you don't just hang a sixteen year old boy for that -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask the horse what he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - for cruelty. There'd be no sixteen year old boys left. (a beat, then:) Grant wants me to bring the secesh delegates to Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... There are secesh delegates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scribbling a note, signing the petition:) He was afraid, that's all it was. I don't care to hang a boy for being frightened, either. What good would it do him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signs the pardon. Then he gives Hay's leg a few hard thwacks and a squeeze. It hurts a little. Hay winces. 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War's nearly done. Ain't that so? What use one more corpse? Any more corpses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting the rest of the petitions on Hay's bed, he stands leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, Lincoln continues his slow and solitary walk.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Times like this, I'm best alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is seated at Eckert's desk, shawl wrapped around shoulders, glasses on; he stares down into his hat, held between his knees. Homer Bates and Sam Beckwith are waiti for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln draws a handwritten note from his hat and careful unfolds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Lieutenant General Ulysses S. Grant, City Point. I have read your words with interest."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam Beckwith transcribes Lincoln's words into code on a p with a pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I ask that, regardless of any action I take in the matter of the visit of the Richmond commissioners, you maintain among your troops military preparedness for battle, as you have done until now."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops for a moment. Beckwith waits, pencil poised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln looks at the note, folds it, tucks it in a band inside his hat. 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Have Captain Saunders convey the commissioners to me here in Washington."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A. Lincoln." And the date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln places the hat on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SAMUEL BECKWITH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall I transmit, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat, then:) You think we choose to be born?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we fitted to the times we're born into?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about myself. You may be, sir. Fitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you reckon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an engineer. I reckon there's machinery but no one's done the fitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an engineer, you must know Euclid's axioms and common notions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must've in school, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had much of schooling, but I read Euclid, in an old book I borrowed. Little enough ever found its way in here - (touching his cranium) - but once learnt it stayed learnt. 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Euclid's first common notion is this: "Things which are equal to the same thing are equal to each other."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homer doesn't get it; neither does Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a rule of mathematical reasoning. It's true because it works; has done and always will do. In his book, Euclid says this is "self-evident."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you see? There it is, even in that two-thousand year old book of mechanical law: it is a self- evident truth that things which are equal to the same thing are equal to each other. We begin with equality. That's the origin, isn't it? That balance, that's fairness, that's justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his scribbled note, then at Sam and Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read me the last sentence of my telegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Have Captain Saunders convey the commissioners to me here in Washington."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight emendation, Sam, if you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beckwith writes as Lincoln dictates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Have Captain Saunders convey the gentlemen aboard the River Queen as far as Hampton Roads, Virginia, and there wait until..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...further advice from me. Do not proceed to Washington." 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber's noisy and packed. In the balcony's front ro wall of newspapermen, notebooks at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashley, Colfax, and Stevens approach Stevens's desk. Colf nods towards the journalists in the balcony:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The World, the Herald and the Times, New York, Chicago, the Journal of Commerce, even your hometown paper's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say you believe only in legal equality for all races, not racial equality, I beg you, sir. Compromise. Or you risk it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens sees Mary, with Mrs. Keckley, claiming front seat from two journalists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens, at the podium, is being challenged by Fernando W standing at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked you a question, Mr. Stevens, and you must answer me. Do you or do you not hold that the precept that "all men are created equal" is meant literally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes are on Stevens, the chamber quiet except for a scratching sound: the journalists have begun scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: FERNANDO WOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that not the true purpose of the amendment? To promote your ultimate and ardent dream to elevate -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The true purpose of the amendment, Mr. Wood, you perfectly-named, brainless, obstructive object? 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have always insisted, Mr. Stevens, that Negroes are the same as white men are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The true purpose of the amendment -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens looks up at the balcony, at the waiting journalis and Mary, who raises her eyebrows, then at Ashley and Lit at their desks. Seward watches from the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens returns to Wood.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS STEVENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't hold with equality in all things only with equality before the law and nothing more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not so! You believe that Negroes are entirely equal to white men. You've said it a thousand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaping to his feet) For shame! For shame! Stop prevaricating and answer Representative Wood!

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS STEVENS GEORGE PENDLETON
dialogues.text: I don't hold with equality in (stands:) all things, only with After the decades of fervent equality before the law and advocacy on behalf of the nothing more. colored race -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's answered your questions! This amendment has naught to do with race equality!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendleton persists, through cheers and catcalls.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE PENDLETON THADDEUS STEVENS
dialogues.text: You have long insisted, have I don't hold with equality i you not, that the dusk- all things only with equality colored race is no different before the law and nothing from the white one. more. 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Among the amendment's supporters, including Vintner Litto GROUP OF WOMEN SUFFRAGISTS in the balcony, and Elizabeth Keckley, there's visible, audible shock and dismay at Stevens's capitulation. Mary's surprised by Stevens, and impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to Mrs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd ever've guessed that old nightmare capable of such control? He might make a politician someday -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's startled. Mrs. Keckley leaves the balcony, pushing past journalists. On the floor:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your frantic attempt to delude us now is unworthy of a representative. It is, in fact, unworthy of a white man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving in to his anger:) How can I hold that all men are created equal, when here before me - (pointing to Pendleton:) - stands stinking the moral carcass of the gentleman from Ohio, proof that some men are inferior, endowed by their Maker with dim wits impermeable to reason with cold pallid slime in their veins instead of hot red blood! You are more reptile than man, George, so low and flat that the foot of man is incapable of crushing you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General uproar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet even you, Pendleton, who should have been gibbetted for treason long before today, even worthless unworthy you ought to be treated equally before the law! And so again, sir, and again and again and 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: again I say: I DO NOT HOLD WITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashley sits, nearly weeping with relief, while the chambe explodes: laughter, applause, boos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The journalists pack up their notebooks; this is fun, but newsworthy, and only a few bother to record it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens limps out through the aisle to wild Republican applause. He looks up to the balcony; Mary is looking dow approvingly. He looks down before she can see him smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens sits on a bench, alone, thinking, troubled. Asa Vintner Litton approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: ASA VINTNER LITTON
dialogues.text: You asked if ever I was surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens nods.

dialogues.speaker: ASA VINTNER LITTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today, Mr. Stevens, I was surprised. You've led the battle for race equality for thirty years! The basis of, of every hope for this country's future life, you denied Negro equality! I'm nauseated. You refused to say that all humans are, well... human! Have you lost your very soul, Mr. Stevens? Is there nothing you won't say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens nods, then, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you're nauseous, Asa, that must be unpleasant. I want the amendment to pass. So that the Constitution's first and only mention of slavery is its absolute prohibition. For this amendment, for which I have worked all of my life and for which 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: countless colored men and women have fought and died and now hundreds of thousands of soldiers - no, sir, no, it seems there is very nearly nothing I won't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln and Robert are in the buggy driven by the old soldier; a young bodyguard soldier sits beside the driver his rifle uselessly tucked under his legs. Lincoln is on side reading over a stack of documents. Robert's on the o side of the buggy, staring sullenly at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buggy stops outside an army hospital. Lincoln packs u his papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you wanted to help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is - This is just a clumsy attempt at discouragement. I've been to army hospitals, I've seen surgeries, I went and visited the malaria barges with mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told me she didn't take you inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I snuck in after - I've seen what it's like. This changes nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At all rates, I'm happy to have your company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepping out of the buggy, he hands his folio to the bodyguard and enters the army hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's met in the antechamber by an ARMY SURGEON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Jim. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move into the main ward, Lincoln removing his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, boys, first question: You getting enough to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks from bed to bed, shaking hands with each patient Most are amputees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert. Good to meet you, Robert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me your names as I go past. I like to know who I'm talkin' to. Kevin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President. John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John. I've seen you before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, brooding, waits in the buggy. 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing a creaking, rumbling sound, Robert turns to see T BLACK ORDERLIES in grey uniforms wrangling a large top-he wheelbarrow, covered with filthy canvas. One orderly push while the other keeps the barrow from tipping over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert notices, in the barrow's wake, a trail of blood. H gets out of the buggy and follows as the orderlies turn a corner of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the building, where the ground is bare, pitted wit puddles of water, Robert watches as the orderlies reach t edge of a shallow pit. One orderly pulls the canvas back, revealing severed legs, arms, hands, rotten, burnt, shatt by bullet or bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert watches as they toss the remains into the pit. Quicklime is shoveled atop the limbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert walks away, unsteady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the corner, he fumbles through his pockets for rol paper and tobacco. He locates these and tries to focus on rolling a cigarette, his hands shaking. He tries harder t control his hands, his feelings, but he can't. He has a p attack, crying, hiccupy shallow breathing, face flushed. Frustrated, he throws down the cigarette and tries to hol back tears.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert looks up, mortified, to see Lincoln watching him w concern. He wipes his eyes, his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to do this! And I will do it and I don't need your permission to enlist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That same speech has been made by how many sons to how many fathers since the war began? "I don't need your damn permission, you miserable old goat, I'm gonna enlist anyhow!" And what wouldn't those numberless fathers have given to be able to say to their sons - as I now say to mine - "I'm commander-in-chief, so in point of fact, without my permission, you ain't enlisting in nothing, nowhere, young man." 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mama you're scared of, not me getting killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln slaps Robert in the face. It shocks them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln tries to embrace Robert, but Robert shoulders pas him and walks back toward the front of he building. He tu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to do this! And I will! Or I will feel ashamed of myself for the rest of my life. Whether or not you fought is what's gonna matter. And not just to other people, but to myself. I won't be you, pa. I can't do that. But I don't want to be nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't lose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, driving rain and wind. Lincoln sits by the windo in his coat, vest and tie, hair combed neatly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be fine, Molly. City Point's far from the front lines, from the fighting, he'll be an adjutant running messages for General Grant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits at her vanity in a beautiful evening dress, pal with rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The war will take our son! A sniper, or a shrapnel shell! Or typhus, same as took Willie, it takes hundreds of boys a day! He'll die, uselessly, and how will I ever forgive you? Most men, their firstborn is their favorite, but you, you've always blamed Robert for being born, for trapping you in a marriage that's only ever given you grief and caused you regret! 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if the slaughter of Cold Harbor is on your hands same as Grant, God help us! We'll pay for the oceans of spilled blood you've sanctioned, the uncountable corpses we'll be made to pay with our son's dear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln rises from the window seat, angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just, just this once, Mrs. Lincoln, I demand of you to try and take the liberal and not the selfish point of view! You imagine Robert will forgive us if we continue to stifle his very natural ambition?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a mocking smile:) And if I refuse to take the high road, if I won't take up the rough old cross, will you threaten me again with the madhouse, as you did when I couldn't stop crying over Willie, when I showed you what heartbreak, real heartbreak looked like, and you hadn't the courage to countenance it, to help me -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. When you I was in the room with refused so much as to comfort Willie, I was holding him i Tad - my arms as he died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the child who was not only How dare you! sick, dangerously sick, but beside himself with grief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh but your grief, your How dare you throw that at grief, your inexhaustible me?! grief! 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his mother won't let him I couldn't let Tad in! I near her, `cause she's couldn't risk him seeing how screaming from morning to angry I was! night pacing the corridors, howling at shadows and furniture and ghosts! I ought to have done it, I ought have done for Tad's sake, for everybody's goddamned sake, I should have clapped you in the madhouse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEN DO IT! Do it! Don't you threaten me, you do it this time! Lock me away! You'll have to, I swear, if Robert is killed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't tolerate you grieving so for Willie because I couldn't permit it in myself, though I wanted to, Mary. I wanted to crawl under the earth, into the vault with his coffin. I still do. Every day I do. Don't... talk to me about grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must make my decisions, Bob must make his, you yours. And bear what we must, hold and carry what we must. What I carry within me - you must allow me to do it, alone as I must. And you alone, Mary, you alone may lighten this burden, or render it intolerable. As you choose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her mouth to make an angry reply, then stops, a watches as he leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onstage, Gounod's Faust, Act Three, scene eight, the gard outside Marguerite's cottage, a gorgeously romantic night MARGUERITE and FAUST are alone singing. The Lincolns, in their box, watch quietly. Elizabeth Keckley sits next to Mary. 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary turns to Lincoln. They speak in whispers. Mrs. Keckl tries not to listen but she can't help hearing what they

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm ignorant of what you're up to because you haven't discussed this scheme with me as you ought to have done. When have I ever been so easily bamboozled?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you when you insist that amending the constitution and abolishing slavery will end this war. And since you are sending my son into the war, woe unto you if you fail to pass the amendment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward doesn't want me leaving big muddy footprints all over town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one ever lived who knows better than you the proper placement of footfalls on treacherous paths. Seward can't do it. You must. Because if you fail to secure the necessary votes, woe unto you, sir. You will answer to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage has pulled up and Mary is entering the White House. Lincoln helps Mrs. Keckley down from the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates before proceeding in. Then she faces Lincol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the vote is only four days away; I know you're concerned. Thank you for your concern over this, and I want you to know: They'll approve it. God will see to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't envy him his task. He may wish He'd chosen an instrument for His purpose more wieldy than the House of Representatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll see to it. 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln looks at her, considering. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of what lies ahead? For your people? If we succeed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White people don't want us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I...I don't know you, Mrs. Keckley. Any of you. You're ...familiar to me, as all people are. Unaccommodated, poor, bare, forked creatures such as we all are. You have a right to expect what I expect, and likely our expectations are not incomprehensible to each other. I assume I'll get used to you. But what you are to the nation, what'll become of you once slavery's day is done, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What my people are to be, I can't say. Negroes have been fighting and dying for freedom since the first of us was a slave. I never heard any ask what freedom will bring. Freedom's first. As for me: My son died, fighting for the Union, wearing the Union blue. For freedom he died. I'm his mother. That's what I am to the nation, Mr. Lincoln. What else must I be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is far filthier and more cluttered than before. Bilbo and Latham are playing cards. Schell is asleep in b

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: My whole hand's gonna be proud in about five seconds, let's see how proud you gonna be. 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it is? What you got goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a quick knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That watch fob, is that gold?

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: You keep your eyes off my fob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward enters, displeased, as they show their cards, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nines paired!

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Oh my God damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. You have a visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latham jovially collects his winnings. He stops short whe Lincoln steps into the room, cloak and stovepipe, very ta

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be fucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't bet against it, Mr...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schell startles awake as Bilbo puts down his cigar and wi his hand on his vest.

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: W.N. Bilbo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bilbo. Gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir...

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Why are you here? No offense, but Mr. Seward's banished the very mention of your name, he won't even 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: let us use fifty-cent pieces `cause they got your face on `em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secretary of State here tells me that, uh, you got eleven Democrats in the bag. That's encouraging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you've got no cause to be encouraged. Sir. Uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we being...fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln sits at the card table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We have heard the chimes of midnight, Master Shallow." I'm here to alert you boys that the great day of reckoning is nigh upon us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Democrats we've yet to bag, sir. The patronage jobs simply won't bag `em. They require more...convincing, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln nods. He turns to Bilbo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm. Do me a favor, willya?

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snagged my eye in the paper this morning. Governor Curtin is set to declare a winner in the disputed Congressional election for the -

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Pennsylvania 16th District.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a joy to be comprehended. Hop on a train to Philadell, call on the Governor - 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking askance at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send Latham. Or Schell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he'll do fine, just polish yourself up first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bilbo, cigar back in mouth, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incumbent is claiming he won it. Name of, uh...

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Coffroth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffroth. He is a Democrat.

dialogues.speaker: LINCOLN W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: I understand he is. Silly name. Let Governor Curtin know it'd be much appreciated if he'd invite the House of Representatives to decide who won. He's entitled to do that. He'll agree to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then advise Coffroth, if he hopes to retain his seat, that he'd better pay a visit to Thaddeus Stevens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pity poor Coffroth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens is at his desk, paperwork piled high. There's a k at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It opens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous man enters hesitantly: Alexander Coffroth. 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens glares at him with what looks like horror. Coffro frightened smile transforms into a rictus of pain. Then:

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS STEVENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are Canfrey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffroth, Mr. Stevens, Alexander Coffroth, I'm, I'm -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we representatives of the same state?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-yes sir! We sit only three desks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens waves him into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't noticed you. I'm a Republican, and you, Coughdrop, are a Democrat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I... Um, that is to say... I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The modern travesty of Thomas Jefferson's political organization to which you have attached yourself like a barnacle has the effrontery to call itself The Democratic Party. You are a Dem-o-crat. What's the matter with you? Are you wicked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I felt, um, formerly, I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind, Coffsnot. You were ignominiously trounced at the hustings in November's election by your worthy challenger, a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, I was not, um, trounced! Uh, he wants to steal my seat! I didn't lose the election - 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make if you lost or not?! The governor of our state, is...? A Democrat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's a... (baffled, terrified:) A, um, a Ruh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Li.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Li.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can. Republican.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what he is. This is a rhetorical exercise. And Congress is controlled by what party? Yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffroth doesn't know whether to answer. He shakes his he

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS STEVENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your party was beaten, your challenger's party now controls the House, and hence the House Committee on Elections, so you have been beaten. You shall shortly be sent home in disgrace. Unless. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I must do, sir! I will immediately become a Republican and vote yes for -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! Coffroth will vote yes but Coffroth will remain a Democrat until after he does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wait to switch? I'm happy to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to show the amendment has bipartisan support, you idiot. Early in the next Congress, when I tell you to do so, you will switch parties. Now congratulations on your victory, and get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continue with Lincoln and his operatives around the card table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now give me the names of whoever else you been hunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schell, Latham and Bilbo exchange looks, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Yeaman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yeaman.

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Among others. But Yeaman: That'd count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln looks up from his notepad, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it. 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seward sits at his grand desk, looking on with an anxious scowl. Lincoln sits on the edge of Seward's desk. Yeaman in a chair facing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't vote for the amendment, Mr. Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a barge once, Mr. Yeaman, filled with colored men in chains, heading down the Mississippi to the New Orleans slave markets. It sickened me, `n more than that, it brought a shadow down, a pall around my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slavery troubled me, as long as I can remember, in a way it never troubled my father, though he hated it. In his own fashion. He knew no smallholding dirt farmer could compete with slave plantations. He took us out from Kentucky to get away from `em. He wanted Indiana kept free. He wasn't a kind man, but there was a rough moral urge for fairness, for freedom in him. I learnt that from him, I suppose, if little else from him. We didn't care for one another, Mr. Yeaman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... Well, I'm sorry to hear that -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovingkindness, that most ordinary thing, came to me from other sources. I'm grateful for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it, too, sir, slavery, but - but we're entirely unready for emancipation. There's too many

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're unready for peace too, ain't we? When it comes, it'll present us with conundrums and dangers greater than any we've faced during the war, bloody as it's been. We'll have to extemporize and experiment with what it is when it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln moves from the desk to take the seat beside Yeama no longer towering over him. He leans forward and rests a hand on Yeaman's knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read your speech, George. Negroes and the vote, that's a puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, but, but, but - But Negroes can't, um, vote, Mr. Lincoln. You're not suggesting that we enfranchise colored people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking only that you disenthrall yourself from the slave powers. I'll let you know when there's an offer on my desk for surrender. There's none before us now. What's before us now, that's the vote on the Thirteenth Amendment. It's going to be so very close. You see what you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln leaves Yeaman, considering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln stands in front of William Hutton's row house, talking to Hutton. The funeral wreath still hangs on the behind them, displaying the marks of time passing: faded, weatherbeaten, dusty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make sense of it, what he died for. Mr. Lincoln, I hate them all, I do, all black people. I am a prejudiced man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens slightly behind Hutton. His wife looks out Hutton exchanges a glance with her, and the door shuts ag 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd change that in you if I could, but that's not why I come. I might be wrong, Mr. Hutton, but I expect... Colored people will most likely be free, and when that's so, it's simple truth that your brother's bravery, and his death, helped make it so. Only you can decide whether that's sense enough for you, or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutton walks slowly back to his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My deepest sympathies to your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln goes back to his buggy. Hutton pauses at his door watch Lincoln's buggy drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is seated at the head of the cabinet table along Seward. Ashley, Preston and Montgomery Blair. Hay and Nic sit in their usual chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've managed our members to a fare- thee-well, you've had no defections from the Republican right to trouble you, whereas as to what you promised - Where the hell are the commissioners?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true! You, you...lied to me, Mr. Lincoln! You evaded my requests for a denial that, that there is a Confederate peace offer because, because there is one! We are absolutely guaranteed to lose the whole thing - 98.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES ASHLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - and we'll be discredited, We don't need a goddamned the amendment itself will be abolition amendment! Leave tainted. What if, what if the Constitution alone! State these peace commissioners by state you can extirpate - appear today? Or worse, on the morning -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't listen to this anymore! I can't accomplish a goddamned thing of any human meaning or worth until we cure ourselves of slavery and end this pestilential war, and whether any of you or anyone else knows it, I know I need this! This amendment is that cure! We're stepped out upon the world's stage now, now, with the fate of human dignity in our hands! Blood's been spilt to afford us this moment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points around the table at Ashley, Monty, Preston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now now now! And you grousle and heckle and dodge about like pettifogging Tammany Hall hucksters! See what is before you! See the here and now! That's the hardest thing, the only thing that accounts! Abolishing slavery by constitutional provision settles the fate, for all coming time, not only of the millions now in bondage but of unborn millions to come. Two votes stand in its way, and these votes must be procured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need two yeses, three abstentions, or four yeses and one more abstention and the amendment will pass -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a night and a day and a night and several perfectly good hours! Now get the hell out of here and get `em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but how? 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzzards' guts, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln rises, and keeps rising, till he seems eight feet tall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the President of the United States of America, clothed in immense power! You will procure me these votes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber is quiet and dark. Pages and clerks prepare t desks, laying out pens and paper, filling inkwells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLERK is draping red-white-and-blue bunting on the desk representatives from seceded states. These will of course remain unoccupied during the vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first Congressman to arrive, Thaddeus Stevens clumps He goes to his desk and sits. He looks around the empty chamber, ready and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaddeus Stevens is at his desk. The House is in session, floor full of congressmen caucusing and arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The balcony's packed. Mary and Keckley sit at the front, Nicolay and Hay behind them. The Blairs are among other officials, rich people, foreign dignitaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sudden quiet, then murmuring. Ashley, Stevens a everyone on the floor look up, Ellis, Hollister, Hutton a Hawkins among these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the balcony, twenty WELL-TO-DO BLACK PEOPLE, mostly me are escorted by several Senators, including Sumner and Wa to a reserved section of the balcony. The black people gl at their surroundings but are rigidly composed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asa Vintner Litton sees them enter. He looks about, at th representatives caucusing, or staring up at the visitors. Something powerful strikes him. In a voice coarse with emotion, he calls up to the black visitors: 100.

dialogues.speaker: ASA VINTNER LITTON
dialogues.text: We welcome you, ladies and gentlemen, first in the history of this people's chamber, to your House!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's tense applause. Some of the black guests bow; mos aren't sure how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeaman watches this, deeply moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bilbo catches Hawkins's eye and waves. Hawkins looks anxiously around, blushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is seated, and the place is packed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schuyler Colfax is in his high seat atop the rostrum, the SERGEANT-AT-ARMS to his right. Colfax gavels the House in session. Ashley is at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ashley, the floor is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the matter of the joint resolution before us, presenting a Thirteenth Amendment to our national Constitution, which was passed last year by the Senate, and which has been debated now by this estimable body for the past several weeks. Today we will vote...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers, boos, applause.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES ASHLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By mutual agreement we shall hear brief final statements -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General cheering for this, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES ASHLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - beginning with the honorable George Pendleton of Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause, boos. Pendleton, taking the podium, is handed several letters by Wood. He holds them over his head. The chamber's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just received confirmation of what previously has been merely rumored! Affidavits from loyal citizens recently returned from 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richmond. They testify that Commissioners have indeed come north and ought to have arrived by now in Washington City! Bearing an offer of immediate cessation of our civil war!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber explodes. Through the ensuing ruckus:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ashley, fake shock:) Are there Confederate commissioners in the Capitol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't... I have no idea where they are or if they've arrived or -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they've arrived?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appeal to my fellow Democrats, to all Republican representatives who give a fig for peace! Postpone this vote until we have answers from the President himself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the balcony, Hay and Nicolay exchange worried glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Postpone the vote!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashley turns to Stevens: "DO SOMETHING!" as Pendleton's Democrats begin to chant "POSTPONE THE VOTE!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, worried, looks from Mrs. Keckley to Preston Blair, is focused on the leader of the conservative Republican representatives, AARON HADDAM (R, KY). Haddam looks up at Preston, awaiting instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Democrats and Republicans rush to the Speaker to support protest the motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the balcony, Preston slowly stands, saddened and angry

dialogues.speaker: FERNANDO WOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have made a motion! Does anyone here care to second -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preston nods at Haddam: "Go ahead." Haddam rises. 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a powerful voice:) Gentlemen. The conservative faction of border and western Republicans cannot approve this amendment, about which we harbor grave doubts, if a peace offer is being held hostage to its success. Joining with our Democratic colleagues, I second the motion to postpone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The debate swells again as, in the balcony, Schell scribb in a notebook while Latham whispers furiously in his ear. Latham rips the page out before Schell's finished; Bilbo snatches it from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, man! Quick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bilbo pushes his way out of the balcony. Nicolay, then Ha follow on his heels. Mary sees this; she's concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hay and Nicolay emerge. They see Bilbo running, far ahead Hay immediately sprints after him and trips. Nicolay continues running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bilbo puffs his way across the portico, through the door, up the stairs. Hay gains on him. It's become a race!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the second floor hallway, Bilbo gets winded, and Hay dashes past him. Hay reaches the doors to Lincoln's offic and flings them open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln is at his desk, working, when Hay bursts in. Bilb appears in the doorway, beet-red and gasping for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hay's too winded to speak. Bilbo holds out the note, limp with sweat, and brings it to Lincoln. Lincoln reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is precisely what Mr. Wood wishes me to respond to? 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tad runs into the room, excited by the commotion. He wrap his arm around his father's neck, then tears wildly out o the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word for word? This is precisely the assurance that he demands of me?

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nicolay heaves into the room in last place, wheezing terribly, Lincoln deliberates for a moment, then writes a note. He blots, folds and hands it to Hay, who immediatel reads it, Nicolay looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give this to Mr. Ashley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hay looks at Nicolay, who can't speak; he waves at Hay to speak for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel, um, I have to say, Mr. Lincoln, that this - (annoyed, impatient, to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you please just step outside?!

dialogues.speaker: W.N. BILBO
dialogues.text: You gonna have a chat now, with with the whole of the House of Representatives waiting on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicolay continues gasping, trying to speak. He can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making false representation to Congress is, it's, um -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's, it's -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impeachable. I've made no false representation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there are -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a delegation from Richmond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the note, Johnnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hay gives Lincoln the note. Lincoln takes it, holding on Hay's hand; with his free hand, Lincoln passes the note t Bilbo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please deliver that to Mr. Ashley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bilbo, pushing past the pages, runs in, holding the note, Ashley snatches it, reading as he makes his way to the podium. All eyes are on Ashley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the President:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES ASHLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "So far as I know, there are no peace commissioners in the city nor are there likely to be."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause, booing, furious discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "So far as I know-"?! That means nothing! Are there commissioners from the South or aren't there?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the balcony, Mary looks to Mrs. Keckley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President has answered you, sir! Your peace offer is a fiction!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not a denial, it is a lawyer's dodge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Haddam? Is your faction satisfied? 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preston, in the balcony, hesitates. He looks at his daugh who gives him a questioning look: "Do you want this on yo head?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preston doesn't. He indicates to Haddam with a small shak his venerable head: "Drop it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conservative Republican faction's satisfied, and we thank Mr. Lincoln. I move to table Mr. Wood's motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tabled!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an angry response, but Wood and Pendleton sit, thwarted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaker Colfax, I order the main question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motion has been made to bring the bill for the Thirteenth Amendment to a vote. Do I hear a second?

dialogues.speaker: ASA VINTNER LITTON
dialogues.text: I second the motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So moved, so ordered. The Clerk will now - (a rap of the gavel) Quiet please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise of the chamber and balcony reduce to a rumble.

dialogues.speaker: SCHUYLER COLFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The clerk will now call the roll for voting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaddeus Stevens sits silently, tired, concentrated: the moment has come.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: We begin with Connecticut. Mr. Augustus Benjamin, on the matter of this amendment, how say you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber is completely silent for the first time. 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk records his vote.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Arthur Bentleigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay!

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. John Ellis, how say you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry shouts from Ellis's fellow Democrats, forcing Colfa gavel for order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Shameful!

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Missouri next. Mr. Walter Appleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vote no!

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Josiah Burton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSIAH BURTON rises to his feet. He is very, very tall an thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beanpole Burton is pleased to vote yea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary watches from the balcony, pleased, but anxious.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The State of New Jersey. Mr. Nehemiah Cleary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. James Martinson. 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Martinson has delegated me to say he is indisposed and he abstains.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Austin J. Roberts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also indisposed, also abstaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shocked anger from the Democrats. Pendleton starts calculating votes on a sheet of paper. Wood grabs it and begins to calculate more rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the balcony, Mary keeps track on her own list. She wri carefully next to Roberts's name: "15 TO WIN"

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Illinois concluded. Mr. Harold Hollister, how say you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollister glowers next to Hutton, who's silently praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Hutton? Mr. William Hutton, cast your vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hutton looks up from his prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Hutton, remembering at this moment his beloved brother, Fredrick, votes against the amendment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln watches Tad stacking books to make a fort for his lead toy soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A field telegraph has been set up near the steps, at the front of the enormous crowd that's assembled before the Capitol. Poles are held up in the crowd by soldiers along which the telegraph wire is stretched. 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soldier stationed at the door of the Capitol relays the vote to another soldier manning the cipher key:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webster Allen votes no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cipher operator instantly transmits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFFICERS are crowded in the small room, watching a SERGEA transcribe as his cipher key clicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webster Allen, Illinois, Democrat, votes...no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cipher key clicks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halberd Law, Indiana, Democrat, votes...no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant observes this from the balcony above. Robert, in a captain's uniform, stands near him. Like his mother, Robe has a scorecard, and he's keeping track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant turns his back on the proceedings to light a cigar. He's concerned at how close the vote is. Behind him the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archibald Moran...yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert has been looking at Grant; he returns to his score keeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambrose Bailer...yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk continues.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Walter H. Washburn.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER H. WASHBURN
dialogues.text: Votes no.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: And Mr. George Yeaman, how say you? 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeaman doesn't respond. The silence this causes lengthens till representatives begin to look to see what's happened Yeaman sits, staring ahead, not responding. Thaddeus Stev sensing something's happening, looks in Yeaman's directio Yeaman, still staring ahead, mumbles something, but it's inaudible.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry Mr. Yeaman, I didn't hear you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising to his feet) I said aye, Mr. McPherson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great surprise, loud cheers and angry shouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeaman looks ready to faint. To the consternation of the Democrats, a mob of gleeful Republicans rushes across the aisle that separates the two parties; they surround Yeama shaking his hand, slapping him on the back. Colfax bangs gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendleton is speechless. Litton turns to Ashley, both astonished; Ashley turns to Stevens, who watches, sharp, observant, giving nothing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary updates her tally: "8 TO WIN"

dialogues.speaker: SCHUYLER COLFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Order in the chamber!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeaman collapses back into his seat. The room quiets.

dialogues.speaker: SCHUYLER COLFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. MacPherson, you may proceed.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Clay R. Hawkins of Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawkins seems to have been startled out of a reverie. Sic with fear, he looks up at the sound of his name. He can't speak. Wood and Pendleton watch this, deeply alarmed. Haw snaps out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, I'm voting yes. 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge reaction to this. LeClerk gapes at Hawkins.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY HAWKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (right at Pendleton and Wood!) I don't care, shoot me dead! You shoot me dead I, I am voting yes!

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Edwin F. LeClerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeClerk, seated next to Hawkins and transfixed by his courage, turns dazedly to McPherson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (then, standing abruptly:) Oh to hell with it, shoot me dead too. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise gets wilder. Pendleton fixes LeClerk and Hawkin with a murderous look.

dialogues.speaker: EDWIN LECLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, abstention. Abstention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgust briefly flashing across his face, McPherson cross out and changes LeClerk's vote to an abstention. The chee and booing degenerates to intense argument about what thi means for the vote count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the balcony, Bilbo looks at Hawkins, well-pleased.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Alexander Coffroth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffroth looks towards Stevens, who doesn't look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proud of himself and happy about the reward

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I. Vote. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause. Stevens still doesn't look at Coffroth, but, tickled, he grins and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grant stands with Robert at the balcony rail, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Brooks...nay. 111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a nearby board, a large map has been tacked backwards; its reverse side, the count is being scrawled by an offic who marks off the votes in quintiles in columns marked YE and NAY.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT AT ARMS
dialogues.text: Josiah Grinnell...yea. Meyer Straus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STRAUS rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Joseph Marstern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Chilton A. Elliot?

dialogues.speaker: CHILTON A. ELLIOT
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Daniel G. Stuart?

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL G. STUART
dialogues.text: I vote yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, in a sequence of rapid cuts:

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard Guilefoyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: John F. McKenzie.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN F. MCKENZIE
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Andrew E. Fink.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. John A. Kassim.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN A. KASSIM
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mr. Hanready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nay.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: And Mr. Rufus Warren?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tad is on Lincoln's lap. They're examining a book, the pa of which feature illustrations comparing the varieties of species of insects, zebras, finches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is quiet and tense.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The roll call concludes, voting is completed, now -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clerk, please call my name, I want to cast a vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I object! The Speaker doesn't vote!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Speaker may vote if he so chooses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is highly unusual, sir -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't usual, Mr. Pendleton, this is history.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: How does Mr. Schuyler Colfax vote? 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look of surprise that this needs to be asked, then, stating the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter in the chamber. The Clerk tallies the vote, then passes the recorded vote to the Speaker. There's absolute silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the balcony, Mary checks her own tally, not quite believing it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHUYLER COLFAX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The final vote: eight absent or not voting, fifty six votes against, one hundred nineteen votes for. With a margin of two votes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln stands, waiting. The only sound is the ticking of the clock. And then the ticking is slowly drowned out as bells begin to peal throughout the city. Lincoln raises t window as Tad rushes to him. The bells are joined by a cannonade. The sound of jubilation fills his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln turns from the window to Tad, who stares out eage seeking out the source of the noise. Lincoln puts his han Tad's head. He looks down at his son, silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Representatives throw papers in the air, embrace, weep, shout, dance, climb on desks. In the balcony, Mary stands slowly, beyond tears or joy; Mrs. Keckley stands with her smiling, crying. Preston Blair applauds vigorously. The b visitors join the general exultation, overwhelmed, some praying, others embracing and weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latham's, Schell's and Bilbo's seats are empty; they've g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashley, grinning from ear to ear, tears streaming down hi face, is hoisted up on shoulders and marched around the r as on the floor and in the balcony, people start singing Battle Cry of Freedom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pendleton, with the face of someone who's seen his world collapse into ruin, walks straight at Yeaman, who's liste to the singing, deeply moved, his face full of wonder. Pendleton turns, without a word, and leaves the House. 114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeaman laughs, and loudly joins in singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens clumps over to the Clerk of the House, who is pla his tallies and the official copy of the amendment bill i folio. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Mr. Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bill, Mr. McPherson, may I...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk hands the bill to Stevens, who folds it and poc it.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: That's...That's the official bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll return it in the morning. Creased, but unharmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celebrating crowds move towards the Mall, singing, carryi placards proclaiming the passage of the amendment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaddeus Stevens is hobbling in the opposite direction, making difficult headway against the crowd, pushed and shoved, unrecognized; he shoves back, his ferocious scowl utterly at odds with the prevailing festive mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches a modest house, unlocks the door and steps ins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens is met at the door by LYDIA SMITH, a black woman her fifties. As she helps him off with his coat, he takes piece of paper from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gift for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: THADDEUS STEVENS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The greatest measure of the Nineteenth Century. Passed by corruption, aided and abetted by the purest man in America. 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stevens, in his nightgown, takes off his wig. He's bald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies down in bed. Mrs. Smith is in bed already beside him. She's holding the paper he gave her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you'd been present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I'd been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't bring your housekeeper to the House. I won't give them gossip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is enough. This is... It's more than enough for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. He lies back. He grabs her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it to me again, my love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And adopted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adopted. "An Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. Section One: Neither slavery nor involuntary servitude, except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted, shall exist within the United States, or any place subject to their jurisdiction."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Congress shall have power to enforce this amendment by appropriate legislation." 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thaddeus Stevens grins, nods, thinking, eyes sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sailors cheer Lincoln's arrival. Lincoln walks across the gangway. Seward greets him amidst the cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lincoln, Seward and the commissioners are seated. Seward looks concerned at Lincoln's fatigue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me be blunt. Will the southern states resume their former position in the Union speedily enough to enable us to block ratification of the Thirteenth Amendment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like peace immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like your states restored to their practical relations to the Union immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this could be given me in writing, as Vice President of the Confederacy, I'd bring that document with celerity to Jefferson Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrender and we can discuss reconstruction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrender won't be thought of unless you've assured us, in writing, that we'll be readmitted in time to block this amendment. 117.

dialogues.speaker: R.M.T. HUNTER
dialogues.text: This is the arrogant demand of a conqueror for a humiliating,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll not be conquered people, Mr. Hunter. You will be citizens, returned to the laws and the guarantees of rights of the Constitution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which now extinguishes slavery. And with it our economy. All our laws will be determined by a Congress of vengeful Yankees, all our rights'll be subject to a Supreme Court benched by Black Republican radicals. All our traditions will be obliterated. We won't know ourselves anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a nod, then:) We ain't here to discuss reconstruction, we have no legal basis for that discussion. But I don't want to deal falsely. The Northern states'll ratify, most of `em. As I figure, it remains for two of the Southern states to do the same, even after all are readmitted. And I been working on that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tennessee and Louisiana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arkansas too, most likely. It'll be ratified. Slavery, sir, it's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunter storms out of the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we submit ourselves to law, Alex, even submit to losing freedoms - the freedom to oppress, for instance - we may discover other freedoms previously unknown to us. Had you kept faith with democratic process, as frustrating as that can be - 118.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN A. CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Come sir, spare us at least these pieties. Did you defeat us with ballots?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How've you held your Union together? Through democracy? How many hundreds of thousands have died during your administration? Your Union, sir, is bonded in cannonfire and death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may be you're right. But say all we done is show the world that democracy isn't chaos, that there is a great invisible strength in a people's union? Say we've shown that a people can endure awful sacrifice and yet cohere? Mightn't that save at least the idea of democracy, to aspire to? Eventually, to become worthy of? At all rates, whatever may be proven by blood and sacrifice must've been proved by now. Shall we stop this bleeding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a vision of apocalypse, a city on the banks of a bro river is being consumed in a hellish fire, as artillery shells rend the dark sky asunder, raining down destructio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
